clinical_study.brief_title: Safety and Efficacy of Multiple EPO Injections in Children With Cerebral Palsy
clinical_study.official_title: Safety and Efficacy of Repetitive Erythropoietin Treatment for Cerebral Palsy

brief_summary.textblock: This study is a retrospective review on the safety and efficacy of repetitive erythropoietin injection in children with cerebral palsy

detailed_description.textblock: Cerebral palsy is mostly caused by hypoxic-ischemic encephalopathy from preterm birth, involving inflammatory and apoptotic cellular response. Erythropoietin (EPO) has shown neuroprotective effects via activation of anti-inflammatory, angiogenic, and anti-apoptotic pathways. The safety and feasibility of EPO in children were proven in previous clinical trials. In addition, the efficacy of EPO is actively being investigated and some reports have shown potential benefits in cerebral palsy. To confirm the safety and efficacy of multiple injections with expected effect, retrospective review on medical records was performed.

primary_outcome.time_frame: interview was performed at an average of 1 year after the completion of rhEPO injections
primary_outcome.description: telephone interview was conducted to collect information of adverse events from all patients.

secondary_outcome.measure: Change of Gross Motor Function Measure
secondary_outcome.time_frame: The results between the baseline evaluation before rhEPO injection and the last evaluation at an average of 1 year after rhEPO injections were compared
secondary_outcome.description: The change of GMFM score before and after rhEPO injections

arm_group.description: cerebral palsy patients who had received erythropoietin from January 2013 to November 2016

study_pop.textblock: Children diagnosed with cerebral palsy who had received recombinant human erythropoietin more than once.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- confirmed clinical diagnosis of cerebral palsy based on neuromotor findings,
- less than 18 years of age,
- received recombinant human erythropoietin (rhEPO) more than once.
Exclusion Criteria:
- not responding to phone interview or
- no functional assessments available.
